thread.title: Australia shares fall on more signs of weakness in China
thread.title_full: Australia shares fall on more signs of weakness in China

title: Australia shares fall on more signs of weakness in China
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Sep 2, 2015, 06:03 BST - UK Markets open in 1 hr 57 mins Australia shares fall on more signs of weakness in China Reuters - UK Focus â€“ 16 minutes ago 
* Australian stocks fall for third day 
* Financial sector leads losses 
* Weakness in Chinese manufacturing weighs on market (Adds analysis, quotes, stocks on the move) 
WELLINGTON, Sept 2 (Reuters) - Australian shares fell 0.37 percent on Wednesday on broad-based losses as the market tracked a sell-off in global equity markets. 
The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 18.710 points to 5077.700 by 0445 GMT. The benchmark fell 2.1 percent on Tuesday, its lowest finish since Aug 24. 
The index extended losses after the release of slightly weaker-than-expected GDP data, hitting a session low of 5019.30. It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) later trimmed losses. 
Australia experienced the slowest economic growth in two years over the second quarter due in part to a sharp fall in export volumes, knocking the Australian dollar to its lowest in over six years. 
The financial sector led losses with all major banks down. Macquarie lost 2 percent and AMP fell 1.1 percent. 
The energy sector was hit hard by an 8 percent dip in oil prices overnight. Origin fell 4.1 percent, while Whitehaven Coal (Dusseldorf: WC2.DU - news ) lost 3.6 percent. 
Armour Energy soared as much as 120.6 percent, its highest in 13 months, after it entered a deal to buy oil and gas interests in Queensland from Origin. 
Austin Exploration (Hamburg: JUE.HM - news ) also rose, up as much as 36.4 percent, after its drilling operations in Mississippi found oil. 
New Zealand's benchmark NZX50 share index fell 1.36 percent or 76.98 points to 5,578.01 on Wednesday. 
Air New Zealand dropped 3.03 percent as investors continued to worry over increased competition from budget rival airline Jetstar, which announced four new regional routes last week. 
The volatility of equities markets hit growth stock Xero (Frankfurt: 0XE.F - news ) , which traded down 2.88 percent. 
Consumer-related companies stumbled with concerns about slowing growth in the economy, which could have an effect on consumer spending in the months to come. Sky TV dropped 4.53 percent, Sky City fell 2.8 percent and Trade Me was down 1.1 percent.
